Can The US Government ‘Bail Out’ Bitcoin Amid Market Carnage? Treasury Secretary Bessent Has The Answer

รัฐมนตรีกระทรวงคลังสหรัฐ Scott Bessent ยืนยันว่าเขาไม่มีอำนาจในการ "ช่วยเหลือ" Bitcoin หรือบังคับให้ธนาคารเอกชนซื้อสินทรัพย์ดังกล่าว คำแถลงดังกล่าวเกิดขึ้นระหว่างการพิจารณาของคณะกรรมการบริการการเงินของสภาผู้แทนราษฎร หลังจากราคา Bitcoin ร่วงลงอย่างหนัก โดย Bessent ตอบชัดแจ้งว่าทั้งกระทรวงคลังและคณะกรรมการกำกับดูแลเสถียรภาพการเงินไม่สามารถแทรกแซงตลาดในลักษณะนี้ได้ อย่างไรก็ตาม รัฐบาลสหรัฐยังคงมุ่งมั่นที่จะเพิ่มการถือครอง Bitcoin ผ่านวิธีการที่เป็นกลางต่องบประมาณ (budget-neutral) โดยไม่ใช้เงินภาษีของประชาชน ซึ่งอาจรวมถึงการใช้ Bitcoin ที่ถูกยึดจากคดีอาญาซึ่งปัจจุบันมีมูลค่าเกิน 15 พันล้านดอลลาร์ การดำเนินการดังกล่าวอาจสร้างความต้องการสูงสำหรับสกุลเงินดิจิทัลนี้และส่งสัญญาณให้ประเทศอื่นๆ พิจารณาสร้างสำรอง Bitcoin เช่นกัน

EN

U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent firmly stated that he lacks the authority to bail out Bitcoin or mandate private banks to purchase the cryptocurrency. This declaration came during a heated House Financial Services Committee hearing where Rep. Brad Sherman questioned whether the government could intervene to support BTC prices as they plummeted toward $60,000. Bessent clarified that neither the Treasury Department nor the Financial Stability Oversight Council possesses the power to enforce such measures or modify banking reserve requirements for crypto acquisitions. Despite ruling out a bailout, Bessent confirmed the government's commitment to expanding its Bitcoin holdings through budget-neutral means, such as utilizing confiscated tokens currently valued at over $15 billion. The administration continues to explore strategies like reevaluating gold certificates or tariff revenue to fund these purchases, potentially creating significant demand and setting a precedent for other nations to establish strategic Bitcoin reserves.

Key Points

  • Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent denies authority to bail out Bitcoin or force banks to buy it.
  • The hearing followed a significant drop in Bitcoin price to nearly $60,000.
  • The US government holds over $15 billion in confiscated Bitcoin as part of a strategic reserve.
  • The administration aims to increase Bitcoin holdings without using taxpayer funds.

Article

U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent was recently the subject of heavy scrutiny from lawmakers during a contentious hearing before the House Financial Services Committee, with intense exchanges over various matters, including the Treasury Department’s role in Bitcoin oversight. As the price of BTC craters, Bessent has ruled out the possibility of a government bailout for the premier crypto. “I Do Not Have That Authority” Bitcoin’s crash to nearly $60,000 on Thursday, a roughly 25% decline over seven days, has even U.S. lawmakers wondering whether the government can direct private banks to buy more BTC during a market downturn. “Does the Treasury Department or the various components of the Federal Open Market Committee have the authority to bail out Bitcoin?” anti-crypto California Rep. Brad Sherman (D-CA) asked Bessent during the hearing. Sherman then asked Bessent if he intends to order private banks to purchase more BTC or “Trump Coin,” a reference to the memecoin launched last January by US President Donald Trump, by modifying banking reserve requirements to allow them to acquire more. Advertisement “I am the Secretary of the Treasury. I do not have the authority to do that, and as chair of the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC), I do not have that authority.” U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order in March 2025 to create a strategic Bitcoin reserve, made up of tokens forfeited as part of government criminal or civil asset forfeiture. According to Bessent, the $500 million in confiscated Bitcoin had surged in value to over $15 billion while in custody. Government Bitcoin Purchases Remain A Possibility During the hearing, Bessent reiterated that the government remains committed to increasing its Bitcoin holdings in a budget-neutral way without using American taxpayer dollars. However, no major developments were shared on how those strategies may be executed. Among the budget-neutral strategies previously floated are reevaluating the Treasury’s gold certificates and tariff revenue . That said, the US government actively buying Bitcoin could create significant demand for the world’s largest cryptocurrency, which may boost its price and likely signal to other nation-states the need to create their own strategic Bitcoin reserves.
